content: We have currently test-deployed on this server @Yash RE's work in #11894 on making the top navbar area work how we want it to. Let's use this thread to discuss feedback, report issues, etc.
One thing that I've noticed already is that the night mode background isn't quite right: has the darker background we want only for an active search box present unconditionally.
pasted image

The other thing is that I don't think the behavior of the "X" thing when you're in the search widget but haven't actually searched is correct; I think it should just return you to showing the stream description details.
I think clicking on the search icon should just pop a modal at this point. It's less confusing than using the same real estate for two different things.
The "11005" is kind of confusing without context. I know you can hover it to see that it represents the number of users. Not sure what the best solution is.
It also feels strange that if you're in a topic narrow, the navbar doesn't indicate the topic, and yet we still have the mostly redundant floating recipient bar.

Regarding the last point: I think one thing that might help is making the line below the top "nav bar area" a little thicker (or adding a box shadow) so that it feels more visually separate from the rest of the UI.
(but I also agree that this change might => some changes to FRB or recipient bars)
Yeah, I'm unsure about the floating recipient bar thing. It's possible folks will just need to learn to look at the left sidebar to see what narrow they're in, and that'll be fine.

I don't know if this is part of the discussion already, but I find the fonts a little inconsistent between the search bar and the navbar.
Other than that, I really like the new design, it's very easy on the eyes.

I have a different gripe here, which is the actual value "11005":
I think it's worth thinking about how much useful information this provides the user, and how much (essentially useless) historical information this shows the user.

When I look at a stream and see the count:
I want an estimate for "how active the stream is", "how many people will get a message that I post here", etc.
I don't want to see the count of all the people who've ever subscribed to the stream (which includes all the people (since the beginning of time!) signed up, got auto subscribed to this stream and then disappeared after a few days.) (not useful information)

Would it be possible that what we want is to try and change what number we're getting to be the number of "active" users?

(We could define some criteria for "active", eg like has sent a message in the past year or something else.)
@Yash RE I tend to agree with you that the number of subscribers isn't super important. I would much, much rather see what topic I'm narrowed to, and then just eliminate the FRB.
I would consider putting the number (however we format it and whatever we decide it should represent) to the left of the stream name.

I think it's worth thinking about the different environments one might see:

  • In a corporate community where most users are active, the number of total users is actually pretty useful for understanding what's going on.
  • In an open source community like this one where you have tons of inactive users, I think it's still really useful to see the difference between 4, 27, 350, and 11K (all of which are approximate sizes of streams in this organization).
  • Trying to do something with active users is difficult to specify clearly -- do you want users from the last day? Last week? Etc. And what is active -- logged in? Read a message? Sent a message? We can think about that down the line, but I think we should consider trying to do something around active users to be out of scope for now.

@Steve Howell I don't think we'll get to remove the FRB without also finding a place for the date, and in any case, I think removing that element for topic narrows would reduce the visual consistency of the app in a way that isn't helpful.

One thing to think about is whether there's a way we can indicate that you're in a topic within #design without actually spelling the whole thing in that navbar area (which would likely crowd out the stream description for longer topics)

fwiw, the "no topic in the nav bar" thing isn't really bothering me anymore, even though I initially had an instinctive reaction when reviewing the PR.

I also agree with Tim that the order of magnitude info on size of stream is pretty useful. I also agree we may want to do something better eventually for open source orgs, but probably out of scope for this work.

In a corporate community ... pretty useful.

That makes sense to me, although, I'm still skeptical that the 11k is a useful figure to see on a daily basis for open source communities.

We can think about that down the line ... out of scope for now.

I'm confused about a small design thing here:
For certain kind of filter states, we want to prevent the search bar from being closed, eg when you've searched for something.
What would be the best UI for the "X" when we to do this (because it's normally how you'd close the search filter)?
For reference, here's a gif of the "x" when the navbar is not locked.

A few things we could do are:

  • we could just disable the click listener without changing the appearance. But this might seem like something broken rather than something intended.
  • we could hide the "X"
  • we could change the function of the "X" on locked narrows so that it just clears the search.

What would seem better? @Anders Kaseorg @Rishi Gupta
Can you explain what “locked” means?
I don’t see why we the user should ever be prevented from closing the search bar.
The behavior I expect is that the “×” closes the search bar and clears the search, returning you to whatever base view is selected in the left sidebar.
Yeah, I agree, the behavior in this corner case should be to clear the search rather than just closing the search bar.
(We may eventually need an algorithm to determine where to return you to, but for now, it should be the same behavior that clearing search has on master)
Clearing search on master also unnarrows. I don’t think that makes sense with the new design, since narrowing is no longer presented as if it were a search.

@Anders Kaseorg by "locked" I just mean the state where we don't allow the search to be closed.

When we're not in a "stream based narrow" ie when we're not "stream: something", the navbar doesn't really have much to show the user, it would just be some text saying "search results" or a similar title. The search bar on the other hand has the exact filter and also the search query, which is useful to explain what the user is looking at. (This "locked" behavior actually came about as a way to handle narrows that we don't have a title for, eg is:alerted or combinations of such filters).

I hope that makes sense.
In that case, I’m questioning the premise that the navbar should ever be locked.

If the current filter is “is:alerted stream:foo”, then closing the search bar should go back to “stream:foo”. If the current filter is “is:alerted”, then closing the search bar should go back to “”, i.e. all messages.
I haven’t looked at the code here, but we must be aware of this mapping at some level in order to show the appropriate item as selected on the left sidebar.

Right, I appreciate that perspective and if people agree that's how it should be, it wouldn't be too hard to make it like that.

The code is essentially a bunch of conditionals which call a function "make tab data" which has a string parameter called "title".
